question.para: What is the norm of a vector?

answer.para: Same as the distance between two points

info.para: Not quite! While the formula for the distance between two points and the formula with which we compute the norm of a vector appear to be the same, the concepts of ‘distance between two points’ and ‘vector’ are very distinct. So the norm of a vector is not the same as the distance between two points.

answer.para: Same as the length of an arrow

info.para: Almost right! - You need to specify which arrow you are taking the length of!

answer.para: The norm of a vector \Vect{x} is the length of any arrow representing \Vect{x}.
